subject: Economics
title: Loss Aversion: Losses Hurt Twice as Much as Gains Feel Good
description: Learn Loss Aversion: Losses Hurt Twice as Much as Gains Feel Good in one minute.

hook.text: Finding $100 feels nice. Losing $100 feels devastating. The pain of loss is roughly twice the pleasure of an equal gain.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky discovered that humans aren't wired to weigh gains and losses equally. Losses loom larger.

discovery.text: Investors hold losers too long (avoiding the pain of loss) and sell winners too early (locking in gains).

twist.text: Companies use loss aversion in marketing: 'Don't miss out!' is more powerful than 'Great opportunity!

climax.text: Loss aversion means humans are not optimizers â€” we're protectors. Avoiding loss matters more than seeking gain.

punchline.text: We don't play to win. We play not to lose.

quiz.question: How strong is loss aversion compared to gains?
options: Losses hurt about twice as much as equivalent gains feel good
